title: Location Fashion Photography Workflow in the Valley of Fire
summary: Photographer Lindsay Adler demonstrates her complete workflow for a fashion editorial shoot on location, detailing steps from scouting and composition to gear selection and post-processing to create a cohesive visual narrative.

steps.action: Scout the location to analyze angles, looking for foreground, middle ground, and background elements to create depth and striking compositions.
Direct the subject to interact physically with the environment (reclining, leaning, emerging) to anchor them to the scene.
Vary compositions and focal lengths (wide, mid-length, close-up) to create visual variety and tell a story, similar to movie cinematography.
Select specific lenses for different effects: 50mm f/1.2 for shallow depth of field, 24-70mm f/2.8 for flexibility, and 15-35mm f/2.8 for dramatic wide angles.
Coordinate wardrobe styling to mimic the environment's shapes and color palette (reds, oranges, maroons).
Utilize natural light on an overcast day by positioning the model to avoid dark eye shadows, skipping strobes to maintain an organic mood.
Post-process images to unify the color palette and add saturation to compensate for flat lighting conditions.

key_takeaways: Create depth by utilizing foreground, middle ground, and background elements during scouting.
Ensure the model interacts with the environment rather than just standing in front of it.
Shoot a variety of focal lengths (establishing, mid, close-up) to keep the viewer engaged.
Match wardrobe colors to the location to create a cohesive aesthetic.
Use post-processing to enhance color and mood, especially when working with flat natural light.
